ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about literature and reading literature! I learned about time management, because it was so much reading in such a short amount of time!

The texts you read in this course prompt you to think deeply about how and why people respond to a plague, what a plague reveals about individuals and societies, and how plague narratives help us to make sense of our worlds.
Read plague narratives including by Mary Shelley, Albert Camus, Philip Roth; light discussion on the science of plague, but mainly centered on literary depictions of plague

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Some strengths include the way the professor ran the class! He made sure everyone got the chance to speak, and he brought some brilliant ideas himself.
Strengths: all of the texts tie together beautifully, the open ended essays allow you to explore really whatever you want

strengths: interesting texts, many classics by great authors 
weaknesses: class discussions were quite unstructured and not really rooted in text; conversation did not really build on itself nor were people's thoughts challenged/questioned; felt like everyone was just adding their own two cents on any topic of their choice

The course has an excellent reading list, and the discussions are always fascinating. Prof. Berger has good insight to share on each text  but also gives the proper amount of space for students to work through their own ideas. The essay assignments are manageable, and Prof. Berger is an extremely thoughtful reader. The main thing I could see being improved is that theres little to no wrap-up at the end of the course.

The class was unique and the syllabus was awesome. Furthermore, the professor was great! We explored each text in depth, and I think I learned a lot every class. I do think a little more cohesion would've been appreciated. That is, I would've liked if we had really highlighted the inter-textual trends/themes that we discussed. Certainly, the texts seemed all to be mutually relevant, and I think this could've been emphasized a little more. Thus, we might've really arrived at ways of reading other "literatures of the plague"those not on the syllabus.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! It was a great course, just make sure to learn time management before hand - so many readings!

Absolutely! This class will revolutionize how you think about plagues (its not just the Black Death!). The reading list is truly phenomenal and you will walk away with at least one of them changing your life.

yes, if you are interested in the readings. there are many great texts covered in this course. that said, take this course for the texts, not the class discussion. i felt the class discussion was quite flat and not really rooted in text. often felt like we were discussing plot points, not really building an analysis and definitely not challenging others' opinions in the class.

Yes! Prof. Berger is a man well worth knowing  kind and engaging. Obviously its a very relevant topic for our time, and so many of the books are must-reads. It covers ground from the Bible and Illiad through a Phillip Roth book published 2011. Could swap out DS literature for this class and everyone would be the better for it. Basically: if youre at all interested in literature, this is a great class. If you are only interested in plague, the books and discussions will still be worthwhile but you might find that they are a bit too literary.
Yes! You'll learn a lot, and you'll really improve your writing via detailed (yet fair) feedback. The syllabus is great and the discussions are interesting.
